> I think you are mixing up zooming-in approaches with zooming-out approaches
> here.  These interpolations you have listed here are generally for
> interpolation between pixels when zooming in*.  Zooming-out most commonly
> works by averaging pixels in an area.  I would not normally think of it as
> expensive, but I guess it depends whether you have to recalculate it over
> and over...

All of our scale transformations are zooming out.  And, we do have to
calculate it over and over since the eye is constantly able to move,
rotate, and zoom.  Area averaging winds up taking about twice as long
as bilinear, but bilinear is very choppy and loses a lot of
information.  I think our networks are each performing somewhere on
the order of 100-200 steps per image and about 20 images per
generation (is that right, Derek?)

> How about providing the net with Min(area) and Max(area)?  When you get
> down to a single pixel, they are the same.  

It does have a min zoom factor.  It can not zoom out any farther than
it taked to see the entire surface.  So, for example, if the eye size
is 5x5 and the surface size is 50x50, the zoom factor will be between
100% (zoomed all the way in, it sees a 5x5 area of the raw surface)
and 10% (zoomed all the way out, it sees a "blurred" 50x50 area).

> Is the area always square?  (and it so, why? :)  

Square is all we've done so far, but it should support rectangular areas.  

> Is it axis aligned?

What do you mean by "axis aligned"?.  We allow rotations in increments
smaller than 90 degrees, if that's what you mean.
